description: Nikola Petrak, invoking his years of Council experience and trusted status among city elders, publicly suspends all BCI scoring and city business. He calls for a 'Memory Day'—an open invitation for citizens to reflect, share stories, and decide the city’s direction together.

Thousands gather in public squares. Residents recount personal harms and lost opportunities under BCI, alongside stories of solidarity and defiance. With enforcement paused, community-led storytelling and honest debate replace official narratives.

Oksana Lintz and other respected figures organize an assembly for drafting new community guidelines. The process is collaborative and BCI-free, drawing wide participation from citizens and former system operators alike.
After days of public discussion, a spontaneous citywide vote is held. The majority rejects any return to BCI-based rule, signaling a shared desire for human-centered governance.
The Council attempts to revive BCI scoring, but citizens sector-wide refuse to comply, demonstrating a united rejection of automated control and marking Stenograd’s break from machine rule.
